properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind chill values in the -45 to -55 range has spread across northern Manitoba. These extreme wind chill values will moderate for most regions later today. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant√© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T19:59:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-12T13:54:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4201021461.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Bad weather expected this evening and overnight tonight. Intense flurries and strong winds are expected this evening or overnight tonight, momentarily reducing visibilities to near zero in snow and blowing snow. Then, a significant drop in temperatures is expected, which could make some roads icy and slippery. The intense cold will settle during the day on Thursday, and wind chill values could reach between minus 36 and minus 40 Friday morning. Driving conditions may be hazardous at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-13T01:41:45-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for a brief but intense snow squall as a sharp cold front passes late this evening or overnight. The cold front is currently located just north of Pikangikum to Webequie. Intense snowfall is possible along this front as it tracks southeastward tonight. The front may reach Ogoki to Pickle Lake around midnight. Near zero visibility is expected in snow and blowing snow. Snowfall accumulations up to 5 centimetres are possible by the time the cold front passes. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T15:59:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-12T02:52:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0652603292.2020
Area: Pikangikum - Poplar Hill - MacDowell, Summer Beaver - Wunnummin Lake - Kingfisher Lake, Pickle Lake - Cat Lake, Webequie, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

The snow squall is expected to extend from Winisk River Provincial Park to Weagamow Lake to Deer Lake early this evening and move southeastward. The line may reach Ogoki to Pickle Lake around midnight. Near zero visibility is expected in snow and blowing snow. Snowfall accumulations up to 5 centimetres are possible by the time the cold front passes. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind chill values in the -45 to -50 range are expected tonight and also Wednesday night. Wind chill values over regions closer to Hudson Bay may reach the -45 to -50 range again Thursday night. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Limited visibilities in blowing snow likely beginning Wednesday afternoon. Weather models indicate the next Pacific low will reach the Gulf of Alaska Wednesday afternoon while a stubborn arctic ridge holds over the N.W.T. Between the two features, a strong pressure gradient will develop late Wednesday, forcing strong easterly winds through the gaps in the Richardson Mountains. Easterly winds as high as 70 km/h gusting to 90 will develop late Wednesday afternoon near Rock Rover causing limited visibilities in blowing snow. As confidence increases in the severity of the winds, this statement may be upgraded to a blizzard warning later tonight or Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T16:26:15-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Bad weather expected on Wednesday. A sharp cold front will sweep across Northwestern Quebec on Wednesday. It will cross Waskaganish in the morning, Matagami in the afternoon, then Chibougamau, Abitibi, and T√©miscamingue late in the day or in the evening. Intense flurries and strong winds are expected with the passage of this front, momentarily reducing visibilities to near zero in snow and blowing snow. Very rapidly falling temperatures are also expected behind the cold front, which could make some roads icy and slippery. The cold will become intense the following night with wind chill values possibly reaching between minus 35 and minus 40 Thursday morning. Driving conditions may be hazardous at times in these areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T19:40:25-00:00

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist until tonight. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada‚Äôs website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Minist√®re de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montr√©al, visit the R√©seau de surveillance de la qualit√© de l‚Äôair de la Ville de Montr√©al‚Äôs website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Qu√©bec, visit the Minist√®re de la Sant√© et des Services sociaux‚Äôs website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction r√©gionale de sant√© publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l‚Äô√éle-de-Montr√©al at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-12T16:59:32-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will approach the north coast today spreading snow heavy at times to Stewart. 15 to 25 cm of snow can be expected from this morning to overnight with this system. Snow will taper off Thursday morning as the system moves to the east. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snow squall is expected early this morning along a sharp cold front. This cold front is moving southeast and is currently located from just north of Sioux Lookout to Ogoki and may reach Missinaibi Provincial Park to Geraldton to Macdiarmid near sunrise. Snowfall accumulations up to 5 centimetres are possible by the time the cold front passes. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-12T22:51:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-12T06:52:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4208701027.2020

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: Eastern Newfoundland from Gander to Clarenville. Time span: this afternoon and evening. Remarks: Fresh fallen snow will combine with increasing northwesterly winds gusting between 60 and 80 km/h to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Conditions will improve over most areas by late this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-13T00:49:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-12T08:50:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0606421415.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. The next Pacific low will reach the Gulf of Alaska this afternoon while an arctic ridge holds over the N.W.T. Between the two features, a strong pressure gradient will develop late today, forcing strong easterly winds through the gaps in the Richardson Mountains. Easterly winds as high as 70 km/h gusting to 90 will develop late this afternoon near Rock River causing limited visibilities in blizzard conditions. Winds will ease and visibilities will improve early Thursday as the low moves eastward and weakens. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-13T04:17:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-12T12:18:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0891266425.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of snow will affect the morning commute this morning. Total snowfall: near 10 cm. Locations: All of Nova Scotia except for the the counties of Digby, Yarmouth and Shelburne. Time span: this morning. Remarks: Snow will continue before tapering off later this morning. The timing of the snow could have impacts on the morning commute in many parts of the province this morning. Another system will bring more snow to most of the province on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind chill values near minus 45 are expected early this morning. Wind chill values of minus 40 to minus 45 may occur again overnight and into Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will approach the northern BC interior late today spreading snow to Highway 97 - Pine Pass. 10 to 20 cm of snow can be expected from late this afternoon to Thursday morning with this system. Snow will taper off Thursday morning as the system moves to the east. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-13T04:16:12-00:00
